content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a Poker game made by Telltale Games. It is available for €4 and is worth a lot more than that. Poker Night at the Inventory allows you to play Texas Hold'em with Max, Strong Bad, Tycho and the Heavy.So what is this game all about? Well, you play as 'The Player' and you play Texas Hold'em with 4 pretty well-known game characters. A Characters will sometimes use an item to play. If you beat that character, you will get that item in Team Fortress 2! While you're playing the characters will discuss about life, underwear and other kinds of useless crap. Call, Fold or Raise, and try to beat them all!Verdict--------This game offers a lot of fun for just €4. It has beautiful cinematic graphics, features 4 famous game characters and allows you to play poker without spending more than €5! Do I need to explain this any further? Just buy the freakin' game!This game will keep you in the Inventory for at least 25 hours. If you want all unlockable items you can be found at the Inventory for 50 hours.Score: 81/100

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												A decent hold'em poker game, where you can win four items of Team Fortress 2 game (which is not of any interest for me) and listen a hilarious in-game chat of 4 fun characters: Max from Sam & Max series, Strong Bad from Homestar runner, Heavy from already named Tea Fortress and Tycho from Penny-Arcade(dotcom). All of them are lovable. It could be very relaxing, dealing cards, and listen idle, yet clever chat of those four. For some time, at least.Game have only one downside: once you heard all the lines characters were going to say... and win all 4 items from them... it is getting bleaker. Losing colours and taste. And if you're an achievement hunter... well, I wish you the best of luck. Achievements in the Poker Night are very logical and good ones, but some of them are connected to winning the hand with certain combination. And yeah, to made complete of this game, you need to get a straight flash.Well, again, good sides:1) Proper, enjoying poker. If you set difficult level at hard, it will be quite challenging. No, you'll not win every hand with all-in tactic, like some other reviews said. You gotta try to be a good player. A cool and smart one.2) Not only you'll be playing poker with worthy opponents, but they'll be entertaining you in the process! And every of them has a different behavior, which you'll need to learn for make sure you're winning.3) From those of us who are playing Team Fortress, the items you'll win should be a good reward to play a night or two in poker.Bad sides:1) No matter how clever and fun are the lines from all four your opponents, they are limited. And after you heard them all, in all combinations... it is not so fun anymore. And even beyond that point, sometimes, there are lines which feels out of order. Like when Heavy guy is folding cards before you, and then starting to banter you with something like "In Mother Russia you're quit when you're dead". C'mon, man, you're folded too!2) So the game wears off... but if you want it with complete achievements, you need damned staright flush! And that's a bummer. Chances to get that combination... not high.3) Finally, there are some stabilty issues, especially when you're trying to change skins of background. So after several attempts to change something, I decided to stick to the main theme, the reason of stability.I have two marks: "Khorosho!" (8/10) if you are playing for the items and not for long. And 7/10 - if you're collecting achievements and getting bored with all those repeating lines again and again.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												+ Visually appealing+ Funny dialogue, but gets repetative after a while+ Unlocks add incentive to play- Predictable AI is too easyEver wanted to listen to some of your favorite video game and internet characters say kinda funny things to each other while you play a basic poker game? Maybe? Well maybe you should give Poker Night at the Inventory a try. Naturally, the addition of character antics slows the game down quite a bit, so if you want to really play poker, this game will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. Additionally, the character AI is very predictable after you've played for a bit. Tycho is conservative, Heavy is aggressive, Strong Bad likes to bluff, and Max is aggressive to the point of stupidity. Once you learn their tendencies and tells, the game becomes very easy.It's fun for a while, a nice game to relax with while enjoying an adult beverage. By the time you unlock most of the stuff, though, you'll probably be bored of it. Good thing they made another one!73/100A great poker game for people who don't really play poker. Worth about 2 bucks at this point.

number of helpful: 29 of 31 people (94%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												If you're looking for some long story about how Sam, Tycho, the Heavy and Strong Bad all ended up playing poker ... well, there's not much of one. It's just the four of them hanging out and playing at The Inventory, an underground club that supposedly has its roots in Prohibiton, but offers nothing more than a setting. And that's fine, because really, this game doesn't have a need for a story. Visually, Poker Night's a good looking game. The Heavy, Strong Bad and Max all use models from Valve and Telltale's games, respectively, and their animations are very smooth. Tycho's model, on the other hand, is brand-new, and oddly enough, he's the one who looks a little out of place from time to time. There's also a few graphical glitches if you move the game along too fast: in one instance, I couldn't see my cards for an entire hand because they never actually loaded. I'd folded too quickly and skipped to the end of the hand before the game could make the change, it seems. Another cool little feature is that in the background, the characters will appear as you knock them out of the game. They don't do a whole lot, but it's kind of cool to see Strong Bad playing the arcade machine, or the Heavy at the bar after a bitter defeat at the table.Where Poker Night excels, though, is in the chatter at the table between the Heavy, Tycho, Strong Bad and Max. The scritping and the actual voice acting itself is spot-on, a testament to the abilities of whoever's responsible at Telltale for writing this game's dialogue. Tycho's voice is a bit jarring at first, but you get used to it the more you play, until it seems natural. What's also great is that each character's quirks are also included in their dialogue: for example, there are Heavy's "funny" stories about summer camp that are actually quite morbid, and Tycho's obsession/lust over giraffes makes it into the game, the latter of which made me laugh out loud the first time I heard it. In short, they've nailed the spirit of all four characters perfectly. My only complaint is that they engage each other, but never really bring the player into their conversations. You kind of feel more like an invisible observer than a player at the table with these guys for the bulk of the experience. Outside of their clever quips, the actual computer players seem... well, I'm not sure how to describe them. Maybe a bit erratic? At times, they seem to take unnecessarily big risks or make strange plays, like going almost all in and folding. At other times, the AI seems to know exactly what the flop, turn and river cards are going to be ahead of time, and is able to make strong bets based on that knowledge. I know part of poker is that the game can turn on its head with the draw of the right card and make a winning hand a losing one. But in Poker Night, it feels like those sudden moments are, at times, manufactured by the game more than they would occur naturally. Poker Night's gameplay pretty much boils down to good ol' fashioned Texas Hold 'Em, the kind you see on TV. It helps a bit if you know what beats what ahead of playing this game, as it makes it easier to gamble, but you can definitely pick up how to play over time. Navigating the in-game interface to make calls, raises and folds is relatively simple. Plus, in addition to the new items, winning games unlocks new tables and decks to play with, giving you the opportunity to customize the game's look a little bit.On the downside, there's not a whole lot else you can change. The AI has two difficulty options - normal and hard - and you can adjust the level of conversation that goes on as well as if it’s censored or not. But you can’t change anything about how much the buy-in is, presumably to keep people from somehow gaming the system to get the Team Fortress 2 items easily, what blinds start at, etc. Maybe adding in a few other options that unlocked once you had all of the items would have helped keep some replay value. All this boils down to Poker Night's biggest problem: it gets repetitive very quickly. Once you've heard Tycho and Heavy's tenth Class discussion for the twentieth time, it loses a lot of its initial charm. On top of that, with no real options to modify the game's stakes, you're always playing the same $10,000 buy-in game once you have the new Team Fortress 2 items. Thankfully, Telltale's included the option to right click through any conversation as a means of speeding up the game's pace and perhaps saving your sanity. The only bad part, of course, is right-clicking takes a lot of the fun out of the game because you're not getting those interactions anymore. In the end, for 4,99€, you can’t really go wrong, and this game delivers way more than the typical ultra-budget title. On top of all of the TF2 enhancements, you get the added fun of seeing some great characters in a funny setting. It's fun, it's cheap, and it gets you Team Fortress 2 upgrades while letting you play poker against a bunch of fun characters. It's a good game, even if you don't play TF2. The controls arent great and the poker isn't the best, but it's still a blast.

number of helpful: 20 of 24 people (83%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												NOTE: TL;DR can be found in the bottom of this review. Whether you're looking for a review made in 1 paragragh or in a multitude of them, I hope you enjoy the review(s).Moving along...I decided to do a small review on Poker Night @ the Inventory. It's a simple concept made for a simple video game based on a (simple on paper) complex card game called Poker which everyone probably knows.If you don't... well... shame on you, because it's really f*ckin' fun! (Avoid real money bets though, there's a high chance you'll lose your car, dog, wife, house or kids with all the betting and stuff...)Anyways, Poker is nicely recreated in this video game format... mostly.You play against popular video game franchise characters, naming Max (from the Sam and Max series), Strong Bad (I have no idea), Heavy Weapons Guy (from TF2) and that's it...The dialogue is well done, it's funny at times and it keeps the mood going without boring you. The fact that the AI is solid for the most part also helps a lot. However, after a couple of hours, the dialogue WILL repeat itself over and over, making you skip it constantly after 3 hours of play, which isn't very good, as you can probably tell.The gameplay is basic poker, you got your flushes, straights (and hom... bad joke, sorry), full houses (which you won't have if you play on casinos, more like "empty houses" hahaha, get it?! God, what's wrong with me?), two-pairs, your classic "poker" and more...Everything plays as it should... like a poker game...There is one thing lacking though... and that is the possibility to bluff.You can bluff, sure. I mean I did go "All-In" when everything I had was a "pair of twos" or an "Ace-High" and all the AI ended up folding. Bunch of chicken ♥♥♥♥♥...Anyways, it felt like luck more than anything else, bluffing is supposed to make you feel good, you can trick people into thinking you have a full poker of Aces when in fact, you only possess a joker and a Magic: The Gathering card. Where do you think the expression "Poker Face" comes from? Exactly...The lack of a bluff system (which no poker video game can ever do, I think... maybe "Next-Gen" can fix that, LOL!) takes away a bit of the strategy of the game. However, it's enough to make the game fun enough to play, to listen to the characters talk (Heavy and Max are awesome, Strong Bad came to me as annoying) and to generally, have a good time!And I had indeed, a good time! Even the luck felt PERFECTLY balanced to either f*ck me, or f*ck one (or more) of the opponents, not too unfair or fair for me. I actually remember ending up the very first round of the match going All-In alongside 2 other characters, which was hilarious!********************************TL;DR**************************************I'm dragging a bit here, so, sorry. Anyways, funny dialogue that can get repetitive after a while (but that's expected), nicely balanced luck (in my case), basic poker gameplay, nothing special to talk about the gameplay. And finally, you get TF2 stuff! Only problems I had were related to frustrating luck (some matches in a row just weren't clicking for me) and the lack of bluffing (quite impossible in video game format). OH! AND NO MULTIPLAYER!!!! WTF, TELLTALE?!So overall, I had fun. The game costs (only) 3,99€, on sale, you can get it for 0,99€ or even less! It's a perfect game to spend your time in work breaks (lengthier matches won't last more than ~45 minutes (and even that's pushing it!)).The obligatory gaming industry scoring system for Poker Night @ the Inventory is an arbitrarily pointless 8/10.Small review my♥♥♥♥♥ Ugh!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
"I AM SORRY. I DO NOT HAVE THIS MONEY... I DID, BUT SASHA HAS BEEN VERY GOOD LATELY, AND I WANTED TO GET HER GIFTS. THE MONEY IS GONE. I HAVE NO CHOICE..."Telltale Games - these dudes got it in their name. They're able to put some kind of story even into the poker based game. Isn't that awesome? Instead of basic poker game with just table and cards on table, no dialogues, annoying dealer and just that feeling when the only thing you are focusing on are the cards, Poker Night at the Inventory make you feel that you're really part of the game, part of the table and fellas around you are "real". Graphics are just awesome, dialogues are very very very-well written, your company is well-choosen. Most probably it'll get repetetive after 100/200 hands but when you play for special items, it really freshen up the gameplay. Dialogues are also very repetetive after while, but they are so great, that possibility it gets annoying for you is very low.After few hours in, when you win all the items, and fully enjoy it and all you want to to before uninstalling the game is 100% achievements, the fact that few of them are luck based really ruin the day for you. Getting Straight Flush or Quads is really rare. Me myself, I got Quads twice and Straight Flush once. It's random algorithm so some of you may get Straight Flush even at the start of your very first hand.This game cost 4,99 dollars, during sale 0,99. If we take into consideration, what kind of stupid and bad games are there available for way more than that, 0,99 is absolutely nothing and don't even think twice about it. Same goes with Poker Night at the Inventory 2.However, Governor of Poker 2 is better game for me, as it was that thing which brought me into real-life and online poker. Hopefully I'll do review for GoP2 soon, and I fully recommend you those three games if you're fan of poker!Bonus Point: Strong BadRating: 7/10

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I am recommending this game solely for the humor between the various characters in it - they are, for the most part, witty and original, and their nicknames for eachother are great (Heavy calls Strongbad "Tiny Heavy", during some great moments). The only character I was very whatever about was Tycho, he comes off as a pompous annoying know-it-all, but it only gives the others an opportunity to crack wise at his expense. The actual gamepay should be simple enough right? No. The poker mechanics are horrendous. On occassion you will find that a pair of whatevers will beat a flush, or any other weird combination. The actual gameplay has been riddled with bugs like this since release, and that was several years ago. This is the major downside to this game, but the humor completely makes it worth it nonetheless.Another minor downside, if you can even call it that, is that the achievements are moronic. One achievement asks you to get a straight flush, the probability of getting that in Texas Hold 'Em "is approximately 0.0311% (0.0032% for royal flush and 0.0279% for non-royal straight flush)". Other such achievements include "Get a hand with 3 kings", "Get 4 of a kind", and so on. While sure, getting these cards would be quite an achievement, it is still a major nuisance if it is the only achievement you lack from having 100% of the achievements - even for someone (like myself) who does not strive for 100%'ing achievements, lacking that ONE achievement would make anyone want to go for it.Nonetheless, game is recommended still, it is very funny and witty, and makes for a great pastime.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Everything is better with a group of friends!Everyone knows doing pretty much anything feels more fun with a group of frineds, or even just with fun and friendly people. And that's how Poker Night at the Inventory feels like!The players in Poker Night at the Inventory may not be the most friendly ones but they certainly are fun to listen to. You are placed in a poker table with Max from Sam & max, Heavy from Team Fortress 2, Tycho from Penny Arcade and Strong Bads from Homestar Runner. If you are familiar with these names you may notice that they aren't the most friendly faces but that doesn't mean it'd be annoying or unfun to listen to them while they're babbling about random stuff.Aside from the funny dialogue theres not much going on with the game. It's Texas Hold'em with colorful characters and neat graphics. It's basic yet fun. If you are fan of Texas Hold'em and video games you will most likely enjoy this game.One of the main selling points for this game are the rewards your opponents can place as a bet if they don't have enough cash with them. If you win them in a hand and they run out of cash you will get rewarded with their unique item they just bet in. You will be awarded with an Achievement and an in-game item for Team Fortress 2. If you are not a fan of Team Fortress 2 the rewards will be quite useless.Poker Night at the Inventory is a fine game. It may not be the most polished one but it holds up as a Texas Hold'em game very well. It has unique style and fun characters and is a game that feels fun to jump into a match of Hold'em while listening to them talk. If you get annoyed of them or you've heard all of their jokes million times you can always mute them. So if you are looking for a solid Texas Hold'em game with some chracter this is just the right game for you. Although if you are not familiar with video game culture you may not understand any of the jokes since they pretty much revolve around the characters and their universes.For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

number of helpful: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												So, Poker Night At The Inventory, the game where you play Texas Hold'em with a rabbit, 2 out-of-the-ordinary people, and... whatever the hell Strong Bad isSeriously though, this game is amazing, I absolutely love it.I assume the majority of us got this game for the tf2 items. If you are one of those people, or you're a fan of Sam & Max,  Homestar Runner, the Penny Arcade webcomics, or a poker player in general, I'd recommend this game to you in a heartbeat.The story is as simple as who you play as: you are known as "The Player", a silent poker player who's arrived at the inventory to play poker with 4 other fellows. The Inventory is a secret poker place hidden from society in case those "in charge" decide to essentially ban Poker for a second time.There you have it, that's the story: Nothing more, nothing less is known about you; the rest is playing some number of games of Texas Hold'em with the Heavy (tf2), Sam (Sam & Max), Strong Bad (Homestar Runner), and Tycho (Penny Arcade webcomics) for stakes of $10k.Now onto the aspects of the game:Graphics [9/10] - The graphics are their own personality, likewise the characters' models match their respective traitsAssets [7.8/10] - I run a fairly average computer with a lot of memory left, yet I run at somewhere between 30-40 fps ingameAI [9.8/10] - The ai of the game is, I feel, unbelievably realisticSoundtrack [10/10] - The soundtrack is stupendous, I love it: I listen to this whenever I need think music playingAtmosphere [10/10] - Between the soundtrack, the dialouge from the characters, the game looks and feels amazing and almost believable to be sitting down playing poker with these charactersOverall score [8.7/10] - The big killer for me was the fact that the second game runs much more smoother, despite having more stuff going on: other than that, this game would've gottten a 9.6/10

content:
Posted: July 31, 2012
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun distraction, but I felt the only reason I had any emotional investment in it is that I wanted to win the Team Fortress 2 items which are only available through this game. This made me ask myself "If I don't buy items in TF2, why did I buy this game to get some TF2 items?" I suppose the answer is that I get to play a game in the process of obtaining those items, but the AI seems much too random in betting patterns to provide a truly enjoyable poker experience. Which means you are really just working to earn those TF2 items; and on top of that you have to pay money just for the privilege to work for them. I'd say buy this if you want to win the TF2 items, but if it's poker you're after there's surely better games out there. Or better yet just grab a real deck of cards and host your own poker night with your mates. 3 out of 10, would not bet.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												It's a freaking poker game. How can it not be more straight forward than that. The side conversations and the unlocks are nice. As it stands however. The game isn't all that great. For three simple reasons1) Facing the same characters over and over again. No multiplayer. And no "DLC" or "extra content" where you can switch out the other characters for brand new faces. While it is nice to hear the side conversations. It can get pretty old. Pretty fast.2) Luck. Now while this may sound dumb and stupid. There are instances where you might have a lousy hand, but! In some odd concidence you won. Outta nowhere! Where as the other card players could've easily beaten you. Now this might be a game mechanic or just sheer dumb luck. Whatever the case maybe this shouldn't be a thing.3) Weird A.I. Now, if this was against other players then the game might be more fun. But the A.I. in this game is weird, For example, and depending upon how lucky you are when you start a new tournament. The other card players might go all in. Outta nowhere! Which means if you got a great hand than the other opponents. You might actually win the game right away with no real sense of tension OR knock out half of the competition before the game can really progress anywhere.In the end Poker Night is a perfect game for Poker fans and achievement hunters. Yes, this game does have a tutorial and a cheat sheet to understand the 'card hands' and whatnot. But like what I stated; luck really runs the show in the game. If not then the weird A.I. does. If your an achievement hunter and a poker fan. This game might be up your alley. But for anyone else, you might want to pass.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIOHilariousVISUALCobbled TogetherDIFFICULTYAverageVIBERelaxingCRAVINGPokerON SALEFrequentlyPROS: TF2 items seem to be the main reason many even bother with this, but it's a fun game on its own. Lots of deck and table options, some with cool on-screen effects. Bantering between characters is funny, it's interesting to watch this motley crew come together under one roof. CONS: Weirdly laggy during the beginning intro and generally not well optimized. No display for your current hand means a potential win may slip by. There is no way to completely silence the characters, making their more long-winded checks and folds annoying (especially after a long time playing.) Texas Hold 'Em only?? Where's seven-card stud!WORTH: As the best Poker game on steam currently, I believe this game is worth full-price. If you play TF2, you're going to get items for it, to boot!OVERALL: It's a shame people are brute-forcing this game for TF2 items and uninstalling.  You knuckle-draggers might've looked a little more distinguished after a few games of Poker. Like a monkey in a hat. Nevertheless, if you are having trouble getting all the items and achievements for this game, I have a comprehensive guide you can check out!SCORE:7/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

I need a Four of A Kind and a Straight Flush for my last two Achievements and it really sucks.

												It's good I guess. I played Poker Night 2 first and I felt bit spoiled here. You play with half the money then the sequel but you get to play with new characters at the same cost as the sequel. You play with Tyron (whoever the ♥♥♥♥ he is), The Heavy (Or Heavy Weapons Guy), Max and Strong Bad with the owner being the dealer which made me miss Glados as the dealer. I just miss her little insults she would make at you but to make up for it, it has a more friendly astmosphere to it. Instead of having Ash and Claptrap having a passive agressive talk with each other, You got The Heavy having a friendly talk with Max about his childhood which I like because it feels less compative and more a friendly match but with this, you get a lot more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.This game is more unfair to you since I somehow got a flush which then gets beat by someone getting a royal flush out of  ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and when you finally got some money, its very little. I mean, I won a match with a royal flush and get $900 from the main pot while THE ♥♥♥♥ING HEAVY GETS $380000 FROM THE ♥♥♥♥ING SIDE POT WITH A PAIR OF 2s. THAT IS JUST SO MUCH ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T. You can change the difficulty which is a ♥♥♥♥ing lie since you are stuck to normal and you can't change jackshit. You can change the table conversations which yet again does jackshit and you have to turn on the strong langauge which is just so stupid. Hey Telltale, I'm playing Poker by myself in my room. I highly doubt I'm a 8 year old who can buy stuff from steam by myself.There is more to talk about but it's just more whining. I only recommend this if you like Poker Night 2 and want to see the characters and here more lines or want the poker version of Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Here's my review for Poker night at the inventory.Let's begin shall weWell honestly not much to say about a game like this, its just mainly poker as the name suggests but with a few extras here and there.Gameplay wise its very well placed you are first welcomed with a nice introduction. Then the real game begins but its just poker as we know not much to say here but fully perfect at what it does.It is really addicting though now it makes me wanna play poker in real.Graphical options are many. On low still look pretty  considerable.Sound track well luckily its very good and catchy as well, makes poker fun in another way.Characters well some interesting one's here. you have heavy from (teamfortress 2) obviously. Max (the bunny) from sam and max. Strong bad from what i dont even know of actually. Lastly tycho from a comic or something.Now having all those characters really makes it into a interesting game, sometimes heavy tells you a story (though mostly hes sad awww). Max well the most least serious and mindless character here as when any of the other characters lose they always show angry faces while sam hes always cool. Strong bad well this is one angry fcker. And tycho well best way to describe him would be to say he always folds unless he has a very good set thus making it most harder to beat him.Promotional tf2 (teamfortress 2) and Borderlands 2 in-game items. A neat addition.Over all worth it?Surely if you are interested in a poker game at all this is worth a try. Good for tf2 items if you wanna get it alone just for that. A recommend game at only a price of $4.99 dollars fully worth its value.A poker game as the name suggests, well paced, polished,great ost,nice presentation and good graphics for its genre.===================================================================Click me and follow us as Curator

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Cons:-Could have done so much more with the game to build off of a great themed poker idea to keep players entertained, unboard and replayability. -Got boring after the 5th tournament.  Same thing over and over and nothing new other than winning 4 in-game items that only TF2 new players would want as they have no items of real value to put into their slots.-Conversation settings need to be turned on High in the Options menu to get the most & best conversations in the game.Pros:-Cards randomization feels fairly accurate to real-life, something that almost all video games & poker sites stuggle with.-Cool poker themed game with a 'Rounder's NYC Feel.-With the conversation settings turned on high, surprisingly there are a lot of conversations where I didn't feel bored or even heard the same conversation twice in a full gaming session, and surprisingly colorful stories that was unexpected.-Has a nice optimization & action mechanics that's welcomed.-I waited a year until it went on a real sale and purchased it for $.80 cents for I & II.  Being 30 years old growing up during the arcade days, we spent like $10-$20 a day where that kind of money actually meant something of value, just on quarters in order to play 1 round on a arcade machine.  So I look at it as fair entertainment value for my money, even if i'll only play it once or twice in my life.  I knew this before purchasing it and decided to purchase it for the experience to see what it was all about and to say to myself I played it.If u get it on an amazing $1 sale then feel free to pick it up for the exp, but you can also pass on this game and not miss out on anything in this current gaming era.★★☆☆☆ Mediocre Game - 2/5 Stars

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												I don't have much time playing this, but whenever I do boot it up it never ceases to be worth my time. Out of all the games, I guess that Poker Night is what puts me through a rollercoast of emotions the most. I get bummed out, I get super happy, I start getting cocky and then I am reminded of my humbleness by Heavy and his horseapple hand.What I most like about this game is that it has some things that few single-player poker games have: different AIs and bluffs. If you pay enough attention, you can figure out the different playstyles of your opponents, whether the hand is good or not for them and even if they are bluffing.And like every poker game, a lot of weird stuff happens here too. For example, this last tournament I was in: one of the hands consisted in a flush. On the table. Everybody gets a flush. YOU get a flush! And YOU get a flush!But I had the ace so I won the hand. On the same tournament, it was down to me and Max. Max had 500 dollars. I won with an ace high.Insane things like these is what makes Poker Night at the Inventory a remarkable card game, and if you love yourself some poker and you do not have the money to splurge on actual tournaments, I sincerely reccomend this to you. I bought it a couple of summer sales ago along with its sequel and "Papers, Please" for the grand total of 20 reais (about 10 dollars). Even if it's not summer sale, I'd say this game is worth its price.Some things that do upset me a little are the little sound bugs here and there, and sometimes it does freeze as if it is thinking. Also the mouse sensibility is stupendously weird and no matter how much I fiddle with the settings I can't get it to work normally. I guess my mouse will be drunk forever whenever I'm playing this game.Also, the subtitles censor the word t w a t. I don't find that upsetting, I just find it unnecessary.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												I will be brief. "Poker Night" is the kind of game you just wanna enjoy sitting back and playing. Sure it's unpleasant at times if these opponents pull a fast one on you and somehow come out on top with that River card out of nowhere, but other than having variable luck (mainly against your favor), it's a pretty fun game. Besides, there are times where the cards may go in your favor making your all-in bet not such a bad thing after all. There's amazingly cool graphics and wonderful dialogue to help add to the fun atmosphere. And the storyline behind this game is admittedly well-thought out.If you're a card gamer that enjoys some good Texas Hold 'Em, or if you're a guy who just loves to laugh along with some crazy, witty one-liners from pretty well-known gaming/comic/television celebrities, this game may be right up your alley. Or should I say right up your winning hand? :P

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Words cannot express how much hype I had when I first saw the trailer for this. All of the characters (except for Tycho, who I was honestly unfamiliar with at the time) together was just something so hard for me to process. I also somehow didn't expect it to actually be a poker game before release, so I had to learn it.Thankfully this game is pretty easy to handle once you get the feel for it. I think most sales honestly came from TF2, where you get some unlocks from this game. But I honestly find myself revisiting this every now and then just to hear all the characters talk to each other. Especially Strong Bad and Heavy, like TF2 and Homestar Runner together was a huge thing for me. Almost disappointing all classes couldn't wear the Dangeresque shades, but I still wore them proudly.Actually diving into it. Of course all the characters are amazing, granted you recognize them all. And it provides for some  amazing talk between them all (and you will eventually hear all the lines if you play it enough). You get rewarded (as said above) not only for TF2, but you can also unlock different tabletops and stuff. Granted you're good enough at poker unlike me. In the end, it's really just that. A well planned out and put together poker game with 4 very memorable characters all from different series.Unfortunately Poker Night 2 was an unfair mess that was truly annoying (at least in my opinion) and had sorta boring unlocks for TF2. Forgetting about that. If you wanna see Homestar Runner, Sam & Max, Penny Arcade, and the TF2 universe combined just to play a simple game of poker, this is definitely worth the $5.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun and surprisingly complex poker simulation. As someone who has pretty much no real experience with poker before playing this game, it's good at explaining the rules and immersing you into the game quickly and simply. There's that addictive quality of "just one more round", hoping to increase your balance, or to get the varied achievements or new items, that's a mark of quality in a turn-based game.But of course the real draw of Poker Night at the Inventory is the characters. If you're a fan of Homestar Runner, Team Fortress 2, Penny Arcade, or Sam & Max, or even if you aren't, the characters are going to make you laugh and come back for more. The dialogue is pretty fantastic, with all kinds of fun and dark humor (wait until you hear The Heavy's story about the Engineer). All of the characters fit well into their canon personalities, and even have playing styles that reflect them (e.g. Strong Bad likes to bluff and act all macho with large bets, so he can be vulnerable to called bluffs but is unpredictable about how good his hand really is). This is what really brings the immersion into the game.I would recommend this game to anyone who's interested in poker and/or the IPs involved in the game. It can give you hours of fun, laughs, and a decent challenge for a pretty low price.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Poker Night is a single-player experience in which you compete in knockout style tournaments. Each player starts off with $10,000 as the buy-in, but on occasion they can barter and put an item of value up instead. If you can successfully knock out said player during the current tournament you will win their item.Poker Night earns top marks when it comes to character design and voice acting. The main cast looks like they've been pulled straight out of their game universe and are voiced by their original actors.The game is great for those looking for a laid back Poker experience. It also has achievements and can be found on sale quite often.7/10I nominated this for the custom award in the 2016 Autumn Sale as "I'll Unlock That Achievement One Day". I cry everytime.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												A reasonable implementation of a single player texas hold em game, with some mildly amusing banter from the eclectic players present to keep you interested for a while, although definitely in the realm of very casual poker players only.The main feature here is going to be the characters brought together in the game rather than the game itself, and it is fun and interesting for a while to see them interact within the confines of a poker game, and they do each represent a fairly distinct style of play (possibly too extreme) to mix things up and add interest to the gameplay, so whether you will like this game is likely to be based on whether you find the four chosen characters/personas interesting or not.One negative is that annoying last achievement to get a straight flush, lets just say unless you are very lucky the banter is going to feel very repetitive by the time you get it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												From the creaters of the Sam and Max games, here comes Poker Night at the Inventory. The games setting is in a secret hideout known as The Inventory, where people from various medias hang out and play some poker games. You play Texas Hold Em and compete against Max from Sam and Max, Strong Bad from the Homestar Runner videos, Heavy from Team Fortress 2 and Tycho from Penny Arcades and find out who will go big or go home. There's not too much to say about this game, it's just Texas Hold Em. Occasionaly someone will toss in a buy in if they are short on cash, being able to win the buy in will unlock an exclusive item in TF2 like Strong Bad's Dangeresque Too? Glasses and others. The dialouge between the players is always fun to watch after a hand. The conversations with Heavy and Tycho are funny as Heavy thinks Tycho is part of BLU Team as well as the ones with Strong Bad and Heavy and how Heavy finds him to be a smaller version of himself, or Tiny Heavy as he likes to call him. The one thing this game needs is Online play, it would be cool having more players in on the event or have them play as the multi-media characters. So in conclusion, Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun poker game where you don't have to waste realy money in order to play through the game. And since the game usually sells at $5.00 and features exclusive content in TF2, ya can't go wrong there.

												Telltale bringings it trademark humor to the poker tables at an undisclosed location called "the Inventory" where renown characters from various franchises gather for a simple, friendly game of poker. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												Let’s face it; most people buy this game purely for the items you can earn for yourself on team fortress 2.If that really is the only reason why you are on the store page, then there are ways of getting those items relatively quickly.It took me around 3 hours to get all 4 of the items, and I personally don’t think that is too shabby, the AI in this game is pretty bad… and easy to manipulate, or at least that is what I thought. All I did was start up a game, if one of them puts their item up, great, carry on, if not… I restarted the game until one of them did. And from there, went all-in every hand in a complete gamble, because sometimes they call and you knock them out and get their item right there. You can do it any way you like, but if you are lazy like me and can’t be bothered, it’s a fairly easy way to “earn” those items. And hey hoe it only left me around $600,000 in debt.On the other hand, if you are looking at this game, not for the items, but for actual gameplay… there isn’t really much you can say, as mentioned before the AI in this game is terrible, it is repetitive and you can start to sus out patterns that the characters have. Their dialog you can tell is trying to be laid back, friendly chum-to-chum talk with one another, and in all fairness some of it is amusing… the first 5 times. The dialog is so frequent and repetitive that after a little while, I really started to get annoyed with what they were saying. I don’t play many poker type games with the gambling and whatnot, but the feel from the game isn’t what I would imagine a real person interested in poker would be looking for. It doesn’t feel like real poker… or a real game… it seems dumbed down.Now that I have gotten all the items, I really don’t think I will ever be playing this game again.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												This game is precisely what it claims to be - poker with interesting characters that have amusing dialogue during play. Probably won't be enjoyable if you have zero interest in poker, but might be enjoyable if you like poker but are not familiar with the characters. It also has a guide to poker, so you don't need to be familiar with it, the game will teach you how to play.A few hours in, while some of the conversations are repeats, there's enough variety that it's still cool to listen to. I especially like the occasions when Strong Bad manages to get on Tycho's nerves. In general, Tycho has great lines, Strong Bad and Heavy are good, and Max... not so much.In terms of atmosphere, the visuals are good and consistent enough between the characters, and there's nice relaxing background music. Some of it sounds like a jazz-lounge version of the Team Fortress 2 music.Overall, I quite enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Telltale Games Nice try...Well I love Texas Hold'em Poker and this was a decent try from Telltale Games. It's fun to cure boredom but that is mostly it, The comments from Max (Sam & Max), Strong Bad, Heavy Weapons Guy (TF2) and Tycho are funny as hell, but only for the first  2 tourneys, then you have heard them all about 20 times and you find yourself right clicking constantly to skip the chatter, Even setting the Chat settings lower doesn't seem to help. Also the game mechanics and AI poker skills aren't really steady , One game an AI will play super tight and the next tourney that same AI plays every hand and goes all in with cards like 5,8 Off suite before the flop... What I am getting at is that it's a fun game for when your internet is down and you are bored but don't buy it expecting it to be the WOSP.My Rating - 1/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It's okay.  It doesn't take long for the dialog to get repetitive (though there is quite a lot of it, it doesn't take long to play a lot of hands).  As other reviews have noted, the players have patterns that come clear quickly, and their betting habits are unreasonable... raising triple the minimum bet with very little chance of getting better than a Queen high.  It kind of becomes unfun because some of the patterns seem to be trying to give you wins.As a TF2 player, but not a fan of the other franchises, I would have liked this more if it had been all TF2 characters.  It's interesting to see the Heavy while playing a card game.Honestly, I got it for the TF2 unlocks.  It's a fun game, but none of the AI seems very competitive, and the play becomes a bit dully repetitive about the time the dialog becomes repetitive.It's fun to play for awhile and worth it if you catch it on sale for less than $5.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Poker Night at the Inventory was gifted to me by a good friend. I was unsure at first but excited when I recieved the gift as I did not know how to play poker but I knew once I learnt I could win prizes for Team Fortress 2! The first tournament I played, had me crowned the victor! Even though I was just guessing the rules and really didn't know what I was doing at all!When I started learning the game, I began to lose my winning streak and haven't actually won a tournament since! The characters at the table are very fun to play against, the Heavy is a favourite of mine as well as Max (Max inspired me to buy the entire 3 seasons of Sam and Max!). Though I did not know who Strong Bad was or Tycho, but it doesn't matter really... The conversations that the players have seem quite real, and I like how when someone is interrupted, they will continue their conversation by saying something like "anyway" or "as I was saying" which adds to the realisticness. The only real problem with the game so far is when Tycho occasionally has a spasm and moves around in his seat rapidly and sometimes when dialogue is repeated. I also like how when a player is busted out they can be seen in the background doing many different things!Poker Night at the Inventory is a decent casual game and I recommend it for fans of poker, Team Fortress 2, Sam and Max, whatever Strong Bad and Tycho are from and people who want to learn poker!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
PresenationPoker Night at the Inventory isn't the most authentic and packed poker experience out there, mostly because it was never meant to be, but it is among the most enjoyable virtual poker experiences while it lasts. You will be simply known as the Player, a newcomer to the secret poker club known as the Inventory, taking part in five players tournaments against four memorable characters from different franchises, not only in the video games industry, but comics and video series as well. You will play against Max from Telltale's own Sam & Max franchise, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner, Tycho from Penny Arcade, and the Heavy from Team Fortress 2, characters that have absolutely nothing common, yet still manage to lighten up the mood at the poker table. Poker Night's magic comes from the conversation between those characters, which consists mostly of jokes and references, and while some were meant to be little easter eggs for fans of a particular franchise, most jokes appeal to a generic audience, making them hilarious even if you're not that familiar with the characters. A short introduction to each of your adversaries would've been welcome to familiarize the player with their background, but instead the game chooses to introduce them to you as you play via dialogue, which feels authentic to a poker experience, but ultimately falls short on how much information you will actually get. Nonetheless, the jokes are what make Poker Night at the Inventory a fun experience more than anything else, but unfortunately the amount of dialogue doesn't go on forever, and one or two hours in, the game will run out of new dialogue and start repeating itself over and over again.Rating: 6.5GameplayThere's no surprise or twist in here, what you actually play is poker, Texas Hold'em to be more specific, and that is another big reason why this game will become boring within a few hours; Texas Hold'em is the only thing you can play, and while it does work flawlessly and the game nails its table presentation, you will always play the same game, at the same location against the same adversaries, which does become boring quite easily. What will keep you playing, are the special items that each character will bring to the table as buy-in after a few rounds, giving you the opportunity to win them if you eliminate that character from the tournament; each character has one of those, making it four in total and winning those items will unlock them in Team Fortress 2, which is a nice thing if you play Team Fortress 2 as well. Even with that in mind, you can easily win those by playing a few tournaments which shouldn't take more than a few hours, and after that poker is the only thing that can bring you back, but then again, if poker is what you're here for, there are much better poker games out there. There are two difficulty levels, Normal which is the casual way to play Poker Night, allowing even the players who haven't played poker before to stand a chance by following the tutorial, and Hard which is the way to play if you really want an authentic poker experience, as the AI will become more aggressive, start bluffing and generally play smarter. The lack of additional popular poker modes such as Omaha Hold'em or Pineapple is what makes this game become boring so easily, as even with all the work put into making Texas Hold'em feel authentic, it's still the same game over and over again.Rating: 5GraphicsPoker Night at the Inventory isn't a visual masterpiece, but it holds on among other titles of its generation, and what really matters the most, the characters look amazing and authentic to their universe, while still fitting well in the Inventory's background. The animations are okay, but they do become repetitive as well after a while, and the visual effects, while kept to a moderate volume stand out well in the environment.Rating: 6.5AudioThe dialogue is what matters the most in this game, and the best part about it is that all the original voice actors for those characters are here to voice them in Poker Night, with Gary Schwartz voicing the Heavy, Matt Chapman voicing Strong Bad, William Kasten providing the voice for Max and Andrew Chaikin voicing Tycho Brahe. The soundtrack fits the mood of the Inventory perfectly and the sound effects for card flips and chips movements feel authentic, making your poker experience enjoyable, even when the dialogue starts repeating itself.Rating: 7.5ExtrasIt doesn't take more than a few hours to win all four Team Fortress 2 unlockables, which is probably where most players will end their business in Poker Night at the Inventory, but if you do decide to stay for a little longer, there are a few aesthetic unlockables such as new tables or decks, but apart from that, there is nothing else to see or do.Rating: 6VerdictPoker Night at the Inventory is a fun thing to play for a few hours, which is more than enough considering its price; if you're a fan of one or multiple characters featured in this game, you'll have a great time hearing their dialogue, but if you're here for a lasting poker experience, there are probably better options out there.Rating Overall: 6.3Check out the full review and a lot more about Poker Night at the Inventory at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=359

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												You bought this game solely for the TF2 unlocks. Don't lie, I did too.However, the gameplay is actually pretty solid, and addicting. The character interactions can be golden, especially if you pick up on the minute references in the dialogue.The graphics do have some issues, with chips, cards and other objects failing to track the players' hands (namely the Heavy). There are also occasional issues when a hand ends and the characters' are in a conversation.However, these really are just nitpicks. The game is fun, and that's what matters really. From this game I learned how to play poker, which, while not the most useful skill, still makes you look clever.Was it worth $5? Absolutely. Would I recommend you buy it for the unlocks alone? Sure. However, if you do, be warned; you will fall in love with this game. Just a general heads-up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2011
												Over time the funny dialogue will start to lose its charm as it repeats, but you can limit it or turn it off completely after you've heard all there is to hear over the course of a few hours. It'd be easy to feel disappointed, or cheated by how short a time it takes to hear all the jokes, but the reality is that this is a small, five dollar download. It comes with all the polish I'd expect from Telltale, and while it only features Texas Hold 'em, is a really entertaining way to kill some time, especially if you want those TF2 unlocks. It may not be the best poker game out there, but it is definitely the funniest. And, as most people will tell you, a little humor goes a long way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This is a nice, cheap game that was probably more fun than a lot of other games I've played lately.  There's just something about playing a game of cards that invigorates your brain (there's actually some studies that have been done that shows that just playing Solitaire alone provides a lot of mental stimulation).  The fact that the game provides a bunch of cool characters to play with, rewards for other games that honestly make you feel accomplished and god-like when you acquire them, as well as various unlocks and random banter between characters makes it even more worthwhile.I've got to say, the company that manages to take a kind of niche concept like this, gives it a bit more gametypes (more than just Texas Hold 'Em but other card games as well), multiple characters, and a multiplayer mode will probably make a ton of money.  I've had more fun just dipping my toes into this game than I have attempting the F2P collectible card games currently available on Steam right now.  I will definitely be playing more of this, even long after I get the weapon skins for Team Fortress 2.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2010
												The majority of us got Poker Night for the TF2 items. This was to be expected. But if you step back abit and start playing the game more, you'll notice that Telltale Games has put a lot of work into making the game fun to play (and this comes from someome who doesn't play Poker as much).Now, there is a ton of dialogue in this title. It's nice but it can get pretty annoying (there is a setting for this). You may call this game fanservice. It kinda is. But it doesn't bludgen you over your head too much.Even after getting all the items (which you can do in about an hour), you might find yourself playing the game more. PN@TI actually really well done. And for only $5 dollars, it's not a bad deal but you probably won't be playing it very often.In the end, it's cheap, it's funny and it has TF2 items. If you don't want to spend $5 dollars, you won't be missing much.Result: INDECISIVE

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A few months ago I was introduced to the basics of Poker by a friend in the "real world". While I grapsed the basic concepts and hands, there's an awful lot to remember for a first timer. This game proved a humorous and enjoyable way to get to grips with how to play and learn over time the sort of starting cards that may enable you to win big.It's not substitute for seeing the behaviour and tells of real players in meatspace, but it's an enjoyable, fiscally safe primer for the world of poker.But man, ♥♥♥♥ Tycho. Guy's an♥♥♥♥♥who'll take you for all you're worth.

Posted: February 25, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory is, of course, a poker game. You play poker with some famous characters, two of which are from other Telltale games. I originally played this just to get the Team Fortress 2 items you can get from unlocking achievements in this game, but I enjoyed the dialogue between the characters so much that I continued to play even after I got them all. The dialogue will eventually repeat itself, but luckily if you get sick of it you can control how much the characters talk. If you like poker and enjoy the characters featured in this game, then give a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This series of Poker games,  are truly excellent little poker training gems. Regardless if you buy this one or the sequel, Poker Night 2, they are totally worth it. Often they are on special, so wait for those, but when they are grab them.They serve the purpose of brushing you up on your poker game. No stress, and teaches you a lot if you can control your desire to "all-in" all the time :) The added fun is that you play against popular culture icons, who chat away with each other with funny anecdotes, but also have their own personal way of playing poker and poker talk.The only downside is the reptitive looping of the anecdotal conversations. While there is a option to turn down the frequency of the anecdotes or even turn them off, there should rather be a option to turn off "repetition", such that once the library of anecdotes have been exhausted they stop telling stories...infact i'd buy DLC packs for more conversational anecdotes if they'd ever think of that.still, a very enyable way to learn poker or simply brush up.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It's okay.  It doesn't take long for the dialog to get repetitive (though there is quite a lot of it, it doesn't take long to play a lot of hands).  As other reviews have noted, the players have patterns that come clear quickly, and their betting habits are unreasonable... raising triple the minimum bet with very little chance of getting better than a Queen high.  It kind of becomes unfun because some of the patterns seem to be trying to give you wins.As a TF2 player, but not a fan of the other franchises, I would have liked this more if it had been all TF2 characters.  It's interesting to see the Heavy while playing a card game.Honestly, I got it for the TF2 unlocks.  It's a fun game, but none of the AI seems very competitive, and the play becomes a bit dully repetitive about the time the dialog becomes repetitive.It's fun to play for awhile and worth it if you catch it on sale for less than $5.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A few months ago I was introduced to the basics of Poker by a friend in the "real world". While I grapsed the basic concepts and hands, there's an awful lot to remember for a first timer. This game proved a humorous and enjoyable way to get to grips with how to play and learn over time the sort of starting cards that may enable you to win big.It's not substitute for seeing the behaviour and tells of real players in meatspace, but it's an enjoyable, fiscally safe primer for the world of poker.But man, ♥♥♥♥ Tycho. Guy's an♥♥♥♥♥who'll take you for all you're worth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2010
												The majority of us got Poker Night for the TF2 items. This was to be expected. But if you step back abit and start playing the game more, you'll notice that Telltale Games has put a lot of work into making the game fun to play (and this comes from someome who doesn't play Poker as much).Now, there is a ton of dialogue in this title. It's nice but it can get pretty annoying (there is a setting for this). You may call this game fanservice. It kinda is. But it doesn't bludgen you over your head too much.Even after getting all the items (which you can do in about an hour), you might find yourself playing the game more. PN@TI actually really well done. And for only $5 dollars, it's not a bad deal but you probably won't be playing it very often.In the end, it's cheap, it's funny and it has TF2 items. If you don't want to spend $5 dollars, you won't be missing much.Result: INDECISIVE

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Warning: if you're here to buy the game just for the TF2 items but you have no idea how to play Texas-Hold-Em, you're not going to have any fun with this. With that aside, PNATI is relatively a fun, (sometimes unfair) take on Texas Hold Em. You play cards against the Heavy from TF2, Tycho from Penny Arcade, Max from the Sam & Max series and Strong Bad from the online series Homestar Runner. The dialogue and conversations that the characters have is quite interesting and funny, and the actual gameplay itself stays true to the original rules of Texas-Hold-Em. The only problem I've seen so far is that the A.I. is a crapshoot and will sometimes unfairly beat you even when you think you have the best hand possible. With that said, with a basic understanding of how the A.I. works and of course, the rules of Texas Hold Em, the game becomes easy, perhaps a little TOO easy. The weapons and items themselves are quite unique-looking, despite only being reskins of the stock items. Overall, I'd say it's alright at the most, but there's not a lot of replay value to be had, and if you're just getting into it, I reccommend you do your research beforehand to see how to play it.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Like everybody else, I got this game for TF2-related reasons.  Also, I know pretty much nothing about poker.  In fact, I jumped into this game without knowing how to play poker at all.  So yeah, I can't tell you whether or not it's a good poker simulator.  Though I have the feeling that it's not, because I was actually able to win quite a few hands using a really stupid strategy where I just kept going all-in over and over, which scared the AI players and caused them to fold.  You'd think they would catch on that I was bluffing after a few turns, but they don't.I really like the dialogue in this game, they chose good characters to include and it's great to hear them interact.  I only wish there was more dialogue when it's down to two players, because the last remaining AI doesn't really chat with you at all.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												*DISCLAMER!*DO NOT GET THIS GAME IF YOU'RE PLANNING TO PLAY ON A MAC! It has this bug, where the game crashes whenever you start the game. It sadly just does not work for Mac computers! I repeat DO NOT GET THIS GAME IF YOU'RE PLANNING TO PLAY ON A MAC! Anyway, on to the review.As all people, I got pulled into the game because of the items and I'm honestly glad I did because I would of never invested this money into the game. This game is so much fun, and you could literally spend hours just listening to the hilarious dialog between the characters, and is a decent poker simulator. However I am still VERY salty about no mac support for this game, but it really doesn't matter too much unless you have just a mac. If you're on the verge of buying this game my one word of advice is DO IT. I'm no Shia LaBeouf but I'm telling you get this game, trust me it's not going to sit in your library collecting dust(or maybe it is but you get my point), so just get it already. I love this game and I hope this review helped. Also the straight flush achievement is impossible so don't bother.

UpsideDownHamburgerHey's PNATI ReviewReasons to buy Poker Night at the Inventory:[u/]It has 5 unlockable TF2 items (which is the main reason that I bought it).Strong Bad is as HILARIOUS as ever, and Tycho is the human embodiment of modern geek culture.Sascha is Heavy's only love!You will learn to play Texas Hold'Em!Max's cards smell like detritus.Things that could be improved in Poker Night at the InventoryMore lines of dialogue!Sam should come in to help Max, as you can see him in the intro smoking his usual cigar.You should be able to win Strong Bad's Nunchuck Gun, and also have Homestar Runner help him.More Unlockables, I.E a card badge, Tycho's Hair (I would love to see how that buy in would end) or even a key for TF2!'All in' all I would give this Compe game a 18 sided dice out of 20 sided dice, as i have encountered a useful cheat and 2 glitches, but would, without a doubt recommend it, as it is full of charm and charmisma.BTW I am getting the sequel so expect a review for that very soon!

content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												Friend Simulator, err I mean Poker Night at the inventory is a game which offers the unique experience of sitting around a table and enjoying a game of texas hold em. It is relatively straightforward to play and serves as a decent poker simulator. Albeit it is a single player experience you will feel like you have friends in the cast of characters, as they bring their unique personalities to the table through playful dialogue. The dialogue is well done and entertaining to listen to although for individuals who intend to play a couple hours at a time, there is some repetition. Additionally this game offers easy to acquire team fortress 2 item unlocks as an added incentive, not that you should require it. This game gets a full recommendation from me, and is defnitely something worth picking up.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Product received for free
 Poker Night at the Inventory  review Overview Poker Night at the Inventory  is more than just a poker game. It is a learning tool for Texas Hold 'Em, a good learning tool in this matter. The first  time playing you will be shown a tutorial explaining what Texas Hold 'Em is about and how to get it going. It's not the clearest tutorial, though, such as it doesn't really tell you what an "Ace High" is or even what it beats, it just scratches Texas Hold 'Em and how it differs from other Poker games. Moving from the educational side of things, the actual gameplay. The dialogue is hilarious and very well written and doesn't differ from character lore. If anything it gives to lore.  Such as Max talks about his scandals to get money, or the Heavy talks about his past education.  The characters feel alive and full of actual emotion instead of just being the background due to this, I found myself actually not skipping the dialogue because I was genuinely intrigued about what they had to say. Sometimes they will even mock you for, lets say, going All In, or Folding the round in means of persuasion to change your mind on the topic. General Gameplay Very fun, difficult and very strangely, not that repetitive. You would think that playing the same goal over and over again would get very boring very quickly. But no, surprisingly enough it actually just feels like a different game every time. Every game is fully randomized and the outcome can differ based on only a few choices. You will often find a single bot who dominates the match, who then just gets crushed by a single wrong decision. The same will happen to you. Thinking that your current deck of a 9 and an Ace are unbeatable. But then Max pulls out an Ace High during a showdown. Luckily enough you're not betting real money, otherwise that one loss could make you lose a few thousand dollars. Meanwhile other times you will pull out a Three of a Kind on The Heavy, who has a Double. In that case you will see a very sad character, who just lost his earnings. Progression Poker Night is known for having items that you can achieve through achievements, both Poker Night 1 and 2. There's also in-game Poker tables and some others. These are the main source of progression post-match. But during match the progression is who has the most cash on hand. You will see this fluctuate significantly during the match, such as from the Heavy winning and nearly make everyone drop out of the match, to himself being the first to drop out. In other, more quiet matches, these numbers will only change by a few hundred every turn, this is the more common type of match you will experience.  Pros and Cons Pros:TutorialUnlocksAmazing dialogueGives  more lorePretty cheapWill keep you interestedYou could learn PokerCons:Tutorial isn't the best Finale Poker Night at the Inventory is a pretty good representation of a comedic group of friends playing Poker. I'm giving it a solid 8.8 - the only downsides aren't that large, certainly worth a store page visit if you want to play against in-game characters and challenge them to a Poker match.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												Internet comedian Doug Walker wryly noted that people eat up crossovers like candy. It's true. Some of my favorite movies are the grand world-building events where companies worked out a way to share profits, resulting in the magic of vastly different characters coming together. Who Framed Roger Rabbit is perhaps the best example of this. More recently, there was Wreck-it Ralph, a charming CG film from Disney that showed us the secret lives of video game heroes and villains and what they do when they're off the clock. It's this simple idea that gave us Poker Night At the Inventory, and the results are pretty hysterical.As a poker game, it's fairly straightforward stuff. Make your bet, call their bluff, walk away with the pot, and so on. The real draw of this title is the banter between your opponents. Telltale Games give us Max of Sam and Max, Strong Bad from homestarrunner.com, Heavy Weapons Guy of Team Fortress 2 fame, and Tycho, the cynical webcomic star from Penny Arcade. There's hours of dialogue crammed into the game, all of it cleverly written to develop natural relationships between these unlikely poker buddies. Most of it is truly hilarious, and you get to hear something new almost every game. As a fan of homestarrunner.com, I've always loved Strong Bad and lamented the site's long-defunct status, so merely hearing new material from the be-gloved email maestro was a real treat. There are multiple unlocks available, notably the Team Fortress 2 items that you receive when you successfully knock out one of the other players. In addition, there are several themed decks and tables that can change the look of the game in minor and major ways. All this coupled with the fairly difficult achievement set (some of them relying on pure card-dropping luck) give Poker Night a lot of replay value.There are some cons of course. The most glaring one is the repetition. After a few hours of play, you'll hear the same conversations over more than a couple times. You can right-click to skip previously heard dialogue, or adjust the gameplay settings to make the characters less chatty. Other reviewers have complained that the mechanics are exceptionally poor for a poker game, but I disagree. However, I suck at playing poker, so my opinion should be taken with a grain of salt. Still, I think that the players' styles fit their personalities quite well. Max is clueless, but he's dangerous as a wild card. Strong Bad isn't a good player, but he thinks he is, often bluffing his behind off and trash talking the rest of the table. Heavy is a decent cards man, but his pride can put him at a disadvantage, as he can feel that a big bet or raise is challenging his manhood. And Tycho, as a character who actually plays a lot of games himself, is the keenest of the bunch, rarely going in for high-risk pots. Poker Night features lots of fun cameos from other Telltale and Homestar Runner characters, most of them quickly glimpsed in the opening cinematic. The music completes the setting, with a lot of remixed versions of themes from the games represented, including Sam and Max and Team Fortress 2.Bottom line, Poker Night At the Inventory is a game made by geeks for geeks. You may enjoy it just fine as an oddball card game, but if you're familiar with the various franchises involved and get a kick out of the idea of Strong Bad getting upset over being called a tiny Heavy, then this is well worth the $4.99.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
Short version: 81%Poker Night is a decent poker game with mediocre AI and a bunch of memorable characters whose banter will keep you entertained for a few hours. Still, if you can, skip it and play the even better sequel.Long version:What can one say about a poker game? The computer deals you cards, and you try to win against a set of pre-determined AI players, that’s it.As for the skill of the opponents, it’s standard. They don’t cheat, but usually play the check/fold/all in game, making it a bit hard to play against them intelligently; bullying is almost always the best tactic. They aren’t terrible, but you can always tell you are playing against bots.So, why is this game better than any other poker game? Because of the writing: your opponents are characters from video games (and a comic strip that deals with video games), and they constantly interact with each other in well-written, humorous banter. There are hundreds, if not thousands of lines of dialogue, so it’s hard to get bored.Still, there is one reason I wouldn’t wholeheartedly recommend this game, one large disadvantage it cannot overcome: a sequel that is superior in every aspect.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												I really disliked this game. Being a (former) avid poker fan in real life, I found terrible AI in this game to actually be offensive. It was like playing against a bunch of people who just randomly slap their money into the pot. AI has a 3 and a 10 offsuit? Great, let's throw 3000 into that 200 pot! Even if bluffing, that's ridiculous play. You're not playing poker here... you're rolling the dice to see who wins. There's really no reason to not just sit back, wait for a great hand, and then hope your AI opponents decide to throw all their money at your down aces with their 2-7 offsuit. The game also doesn't seem to fully understand the rules of hold'em and has some incorrect rules when it comes to things like bet size. A very frustrating game if you're playing for the actual poker.But, that's only half the game. The other half is listening to your favorite characters sit around a poker table and chat with each other. It can be mildly amusing at times, but quickly becomes repetitive, and the poor, slow-paced poker gameplay makes getting through those conversations a slog.

												Tired of playing Windows'es poker game? Try out TellTales'es Poker Night at the Inventory! You start walking into club, going down with elevator and meet the owner of Inventory club. You'll have conversation with him till you get to the table to play with 5 characters from each games or comics/cartoons. Max from Sam&Max series, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner, Heavy from Team Fortress 2 and Tycho Brahe from Penny Arcade. You'll gonna play with them Texas Hold'em and have nice conversation with them while playing and sometimes bad conversations (ex: insults). It feels like you're there with them playing poker, in another words realistic poker, that is. I highly recommend this game, if you wanna have some company playing with you and talk.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Poker Night at the Inventory is exactly what it says it is in the title.  Poker.  Texas Hold-em Poker specifically and that's the only style.  I'm recommending this game for the fact it's rather cheap when on sale and you get some neat TF2 items for beating certain people.  If you are an achievement completionist, you are going to have some trouble getting a Straight Flush.  The odds of that are 1:64,974.  Also, there's no online mode so you're stuck playing against the characters.  They're fun for a few hours, but after awhile you'll find yourself skipping their dialogue when it becomes repetitive.  If you like poker, check it out.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												This game, is an amazing game of Poker (Texas Hold Em' to be exact) and you get to play against Max from Sam and Max, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner, Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Tycho from Penny Arcade. This game has you betting and checking 'till you're the last one standing. Also, at random times, one of the characters might not have the money to join the game, so they put items up for grabs, and if you win them, you get them in Team Fortress 2. To win the items, you just have to knock them out. Max is the only one in the game that puts up two items, that are his Lugermorph and his badge (A Licence to Maim in TF2), Strong Bad puts up he pair of shades ('Dangeresque, Too?' in TF2). They Heavy puts up Sasha (Iron Curtain in TF2), and Tycho bets in his watch (Enthusiast's Timepiece in TF2).Once you've got these items, the only other real objective is to get all the achievements, which is easy considering there is only 20 (15 without the item grabs).Overall, this game can be fun when on a plane trip, since it has character personallities, and doesn't have Multiplayer.9/10, amazing game!

It replaces stuff like bronze badge, mercenary etc.-Demo's glasses. At least they are glasses! Replaces badges too.There's no actual new weapon to sums it up.On the other hand, if you wanna learn how to play poker texas hold em', it's good for you.I was hoping online play... Single player isn't that much interresting, beside going for the achivements.Then again, it's 5$. Is it worth it? Yes. It's 5$ anyway...Overall: 6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2013
												If you are looking at this game, odds are you are looking at the Team Fortress 2 items it unlocks as you progress through the game. And really, that's the main concept behind the game. That doesn't necessarily mean the game is "bad", just not worth replaying. Telltale does provide us with some humorous commentary from the franchises involved such as Sam & Max and Team Fortress, this keeps the game from wearing out quicker than it usually does. The poker itself is pretty unremarkable, however, but the dialogue keeps it going. As you beat your opponents and unlock items for TF2, the dialogue does lose its humor and becomes repetitive. And once you do collect the last item, there's really no reason to play again, and it seems that was Telltale was going for in this game. Unless you play TF2 (and care about cosmetic items) or are die-hard fans of the franchises, there's no reason to purchase this game. Despite this, the game is worth the price tag of $5 for the funny commentary and items you receive as you play.
