content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												If you love Texas Hold 'em and these classic video game icons, you'll love Poker Night at the Inventory! In this game you get to enjoy the many different funny dialogue from the characters Max, Strong Bad, The Heavy, and Tycho. However, if you enjoy Poker as much as I do you'll find the dialogue will become stale after a while if you play for extended periods of time. Though how frequent the characters chat can be changed in the options. If you get Poker Night solely on the purpose of playing Texas Hold 'em I would advise against it as the difficulty is novice at best. Even the harder difficulty you'll find yourself winning quite easily if you're a somewhat seasoned player of Poker. Ultimately, if you enjoy the humor and personalities of these characters and are a novice to Poker than this game is for you. If you're somebody looking for a Poker game, then I'm afraid you've come to the wrong place. 78/100

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Seems to be a reasonable laid-back poker game that isn't after money farming, which is relatively hard to find these days in regards to the concept of gambling. Poker Night hunts after the fun factor of card games and laces it in supporting 3D aesthetics.Summary:Pros:- Consumes a great deal of time- Non-competitive- Laid back atmosphereCons:- Singleplayer only- Dialogue is repetitive- Raising difficulty by increasing odds for participants to have a good hand on drawThrough the first hours the comments of the participants are fairly hilarious but soon they get repetitive. The game's basically good to consume time for maybe an hour of play a day but that's all. It isn't really competitive on a multiplayer perspective, because it's purely singleplayer, which yet again backs up the vision that inspired the game.The gameplay is very atmospheric and sets up the sphere of a cynically comical mob saloon as a setting. If you're looking for something non-competitive outside of playing MMOs and the likes and love card games, texas hold 'em to be precise, then this is for you.I don't like how they try to make the game harder when you get further into the game by increasing the odds of your participants having a good hand. At least, that's how it feels. Gambling really isn't a level-based thing and should never be, so it's just stupid. All participants should have equal odds.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Highly recommended as a cheap thrill if you can pick this up during a sale. The characters are a little zany and are enjoyable to listen to if you're familiar with their backgrounds. However, I've also noticed that dialogue does get repetitive, especially in situations where most of the CPU players are busted leaving you alone with one CPU player.The actual poker game itself is mediocre at best; the cards drawn do not seem mathematically random and AI is questionable. On the standard difficulty setting, if all CPU players except for one have busted, I've noticed that the you'll get dealt with pairs, Ace-high, or other favorable cards. Similarly, the last CPU player standing will often make stupid decisions (i.e. they'll go "All In" with a crappy hand while also having a lot of money left).To further prove my point, I came all the back from only having $5k to beating Strong Bad when he had $35k. I've also won 3 tournaments in a row and have racked over $100,000 in this game's currency. In real life, I am terrible at Poker and can't win if my life depended on it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I never played card games before I played this game. Now, I love it. Not only does it teach you how to play Poker in the crash-course-iest way possible, but you can have the wonderful experience of being clueless at the poker table for the first 15 games and nobody will judge you. Of course, you'll still have a negative total earnings amount to make up for if you want that achievement, but most people only get this game for the TF2 items anyways.The characters are really unique and a great selection from both pop culture, and what people loved about Telltale back then. Thank you Telltale for putting an item from my favourite flash cartoon into TF2. The best thing about them is that you can make them never talk again if you just want to play the game normally, without the occasionally repeating lines that the characters say. The atmosphere and sound effects compliment the game nicely, and there's plenty of unlockable decks and tables to encourage you to keep the game installed. It's really not a bad experience besides the TF2 items. Far better than Telltale's earlier attempt at making a poker game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												If there was an "unsure/maybe" option for a rating, I would give this game that.Poker Night at the Inventory is unforgiving if you're new to Texas Hold 'Em poker, but can be manipulated if you're patient and lucky enough. A tutorial or guide of sorts in the game itself would help out tremendously, and having a switchable difficulty from the get-go would really help (There's a difficulty setting in the menu technically, but it's set to Normal by default and can't be changed.) Every character has their own play style, and range from daft to impeccible.-Max is fairly reckless with his bets and doesn't seem t have a grasp on when to fold. He's the easiest to eliminate for this reason,-Strong Bad knows a good hand when he has one but is so absorbed in himself that he doesn't take the others' behavior into account.-The Heavy takes into account every action taken by the other players when making his choices. If he goes all-in, you're up♥♥♥♥♥♥creek without a paddle.-Tycho seems to have 2 modes: Fold at the start, or keep raising the stakes throughout.Like I said, Poker Night is unforgiving if you're new to Poker. You may get some good, lucky hands when you first start playing but within an hour or so that luck will be gone, and you start getting crappier hands (or possibly, the opponents get better ones.)There's an exploit to get around this however; If you go All-in at the very beginning of a hand, 9 times out of 10 everyone else will fold and you'll win the pot atuomatically. Do this enough times and with enough luck and you can eliminate everybody without actually playing.The game also seems to have performance issues, as framerates are relatively unstable (though still within 18FPS at the very least and 30 at most) on a moderately fast system with a 1366x768 screen and the graphics set to preset number 4.Overall, Poker Night is a fine game, but if you're new to Hold 'Em then you're in for a hell of a ride.

												I bought this game as it is advertised as compatible with Mac and I loved Poker Night 2. I am sure it is a fun game, but unfortunately I cannot play it and I have requested a refund.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Okay I'm one of those idiots who didn't buy it for the TF2 stuff. And I suppose having played TF2 or Sam and Max or those other ones from which the characters have taken a break to chill out and gamble their undergarments away would have made me interested in the game. I've seen most reviewers haven't spent more than 10 hours on the game so... that says a lot. Simply put, there's about a million better games out there if you just want to play poker. The dialogue is pretty good. Very distracting for the poker which makes you fun. You get roped in by a story by Max and the next thing you know you've called about 7k with a deuce and a seven.There's something quite fun about amusing, disparately rendered characters sit down next to you at the poker table. Each with their unique mannerisms and taunts. Haven't quite paid enough attention or put in enough hours to figure out if they've got their own style of play as well.The gameplay is excrutiatingly slow. Cutscene/animations and I wish there was an option to increase the play speed or keep the animations to a low like you can select for what level of dialogue you want. Mercifully though you can skip the hand if you fold and even the whole game if you're knocked out. Though the game takes quite a while to comply probably it's already mid sequence in character animations.Aside from that there's not much else. No multiplayer, no playing taking your friends money and assets or any of the good stuff. Perhaps a couple of different styles Omaha high-low or 7 card stud would have been good additions as options, without having to do too much work. The game would be worth a bit more then, but then again I brought it to play cards and already committed a capital mistake. Leading me to brand this game Poker Night at the Purgatory.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												I've heard great things about this game. I'm sure it's a great game.I say "I'm sure" because I haven't actually played it. The game crashes on startup on my Mac. A quick look in the forums reveals that this isn't just my issue - for whatever reason, this game won't work on the Mac. That's irritating, but the fact that it's listed as a Mac-compatible game on Steam, even though the developers have said they aren't interested in fixing it, is what really steams my cheese.Bottom line - if you want to play this on a Mac, don't bother. It's a waste of five dollars that could go to starving kids in Africa, or a Subway Five-Dollar Footlong, or frankly anything other than a broken game without any promise of viability in the future.

												It's ok as a game to play to just run in the background while doing other things, but it's extremely flawed. As a former professional online poker player, the game just isn't realistic. All of the computer AI players you face are terrible card players, not one is even close to being a challenge, even on hard. Many times they are just calling stations that play any 2 cards and will constantly call bets to the river with nothing. It's so easy to beat this without even trying, so in my eyes, the game isn't worth buying or playing unless you're looking to get the TF2 unlocked items.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2013
												8/10It's a pretty fun(ny) game if you know all the characters and know how to dominate at poker - I mostly know the former part, but I'm kinda new to poker. Either way, you can still learn poker from the game, like I did, and there are some special TF2 unlocks to be found be taking out your opponents when they buy in using a special item. Also, you can customize "The inventory", which is where the game takes place, by winning lots of rounds. Despite all this, it has kind of a low replayability value if you aren't crazy about poker, and it isn't something you'll see yourself play beyond 20 hours or even 15 hours unless you're that crazy about poker.

content:
Posted: January 10
												MacOS 10.8 was *years* ago. This game crashes instantly on MacOS 10.8 or later. The oldest Mac I have comes with 10.8, and you can't downgrade, so there's almost no chance that you can run this on a Mac.At least the devs finally put "not compatible with MacOS 10.8 or later" on it, but given how many reviews reflect that crash, it really seems like it would be polite for them to, you know, *fix* the bug.So... Not recommended for Mac. Might be fun elsewhere, but until they do something about this, I'm inclined to not-recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The game in a nutshell is texas hold 'em poker played against 4 characters from various video games and comics. The game does have some problems though, of which the most noticeable is the low amount of dialogue the characters have. After having played the game for about 40 minutes the same lines will start repeating, which gets a bit annoying but luckily it can be skipped. The dialogue is pretty funny the first time you hear it but not on the second time and the other times after that.I often felt that the game should have progressed faster since you often have to wait for your turn while hearing the same dialogue over and over again. I might just be a bit impatient, but I would have liked the game more if it had a button to skip the AI's turns.The game is quite fun in short bursts but gets quite boring if played for too long. Unless you like poker a lot.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												SHORT SUMMARY: It is fun for several hours. For $5 ($2.49 during the Steam Autumn Sale) it is EASILY worth the money.LONG SUMMARY:I found this game to be easily worth the 5$ I spent. Had I waited for the Steam Autumn Sale, I could have had this game for $2.49. Fans of wanting to play fun casual Poker will probably get the most enjoyment as the characters are fun to play against and listen to their playful banter. The interface is very simple and easy to understand.The main criticism which many have pointed out is that after several hours, the dialogue gets old and repeatable. Although it is a valid criticism, I was still able to overlook this factor as I was so focussed on the game that I was able to tune it out. If players find it too difficult to tune out, there are actual audio controls that let you decide how much dialogue you want or players can flat out turned off the dialogue. Although the game could have used more dialogue, Considering that this was TTG's first attempt at a Poker game like this, I can find this shortcoming forgiveable.This is a game where the unlocks are a fun challenge. The Steam achievements are also equally fun to acquire. These both combined is what made the game really fun for me. They are both hard to acquire, but not in a unrealistic or frustrating way. It makes you want to get them all no matter how many games or hands you have to play.    Depending on how good of a Poker player you are, if this game is played on Normal, it should not take too many hours to unlock all the game features which can cut the lifespan of this game. However, I found that if I play this game on Hard difficulty, it really extended the life of this game. On Hard, I felt like I was playing against smart poker players that were able to mathematically make smart decisions while also making bluffs or even calling your bluffs. The Hard setting is the perfect difficulty fun wise.This game lacks on-line multi-player. However, knowing that I only paid $5 for this game, I definitely was not expecting that feature. To be honest, I was quite fine with this exclusion as I found this game to be more fun that way. Since this game does not use real money, human players can often not take the game serious and make ridiculous decisions.Beyond the unlocks and achievements, this game has a longer life span than people think. No 2 games are ever the same (aside from the dialogue). Overall for 5$, I got more than my money worth from this game and enjoyed playing with characters from various media genres. There is no question Tell Tale will only improve on this fun unique Poker concept.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												 Being the most HILARIOUS and most INTERESTING card game simulator I've ever played in my life, "Poker Night at the Invetory" is SO WORTH $4.99, and is definitely a good one, just to learn how to play "Texas Hold-Em"; a famous, traditional Poker game. It has 4 NPCs; Strong Bad from "Homestar Runner", (my favorite character of them, who originally came from a kid's book) Max from "Sam & Max", (The insane partner, among two freelance cops, who happens to be an homage to "The Killer Rabbit", from "Monty Python and the Holy Grail") the Heavy Weapons Guy from "Team Fortress 2", (who happens to be a russian commando, who wields a big minigun, who he named "Sasha") and Tycho, from "Penny Arcade. (A geek-based comic, which often has STRONG LANGUAGE involved, but Tycho is the one who pretty much swears in this game, anyway. Though some of the things he says are definitely NOTHING beyond PG-13; as long as you keep the strong language censored!) If you don't like strong language, you have the option to block it out; after all, you'll hear bleeps, and notice that the swear is COMPLETELY CENSORED! And that's why I like this game; it's funny, it has the option of leaving strong language censored, and it's got GREAT graphics! (Any swears said by Strong Bad are strictly be censored, however, because they don't want to make him look offensive.) I give this game 8/10, saying that this is probably one of the BEST and FUNNIEST simulators in history...and the gambling obviously isn't real; it's a poker simulator.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Prepare for a different kind of poker night in a very different kind of club. In Poker Night at the Inventory, you'll deal with notable characters such as Penny Arcade's clever, cunning Tycho, Team Fortress 2's hulking Heavy, Homestar Runner's self-proclaimed "awesome icon" Strong Bad and the hyperkinetic "rabbity-thing" from Sam & Max. These characters come together in ways some never thought possible, in a setting few would have predicted. You'll experience a new style of poker, particularly when hands don't go the way of the other fiery competitors at the table ... because these players have left a trail of victims in their wake a mile long -- with heavy weapons, biting sarcasm and irony -- and when they sit down at the table for Poker Night at The Inventory, they're ready to go all in!Poker Night at The Inventory features fully voiced characters utilizing Telltale’s dynamic dialog system. All the characters will talk trash, give unique tells, and react to the game dynamically as it is being played, providing a unique experience with each round played.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Love the game as a poker game, taught me how to play poker.I jumped into this game not knowing how to play a slither of poker, I just sat down, and played and played for a couple hours, got the TF2 items, and had fun. I would play again. The characters are funny, there are unlockable decks, the whole game comes together really well, and for you who buy it for the items, heres a quick step by step wayEasy Way To Get Poker ItemsStep 1: Start Game.Step 2: If there's no special item in the ante, hit ESC then hit the right arrow twice and select a new game.Step 3: Repeat Step 2 until an item is ante'd.Step 4: On the first hand, go all in no matter what hand you have.Step 5: If the person who's item is up for grabs didn't go in with your all in, keep doing all in's until you get him to play your matching hand.Step 6: If you lose at anytime during step 5, repeat up to step 5 again.Step 7: If the person with the ante'd up item plays against your all in bet in the first hand and loses, you automatically get the item without having to go 30 hands into the game only for Strongbad to pull pocket Aces out of nowhere and put on his cool face.This in no way means don't enjoy Poker Night the way you want to, this is just the fastest way to get the unlocks for those who don't want to sit through hours of poker.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												 Being the most HILARIOUS and most INTERESTING card game simulator I've ever played in my life, "Poker Night at the Invetory" is SO WORTH $4.99, and is definitely a good one, just to learn how to play "Texas Hold-Em"; a famous, traditional Poker game. It has 4 NPCs; Strong Bad from "Homestar Runner", (my favorite character of them, who originally came from a kid's book) Max from "Sam & Max", (The insane partner, among two freelance cops, who happens to be an homage to "The Killer Rabbit", from "Monty Python and the Holy Grail") the Heavy Weapons Guy from "Team Fortress 2", (who happens to be a russian commando, who wields a big minigun, who he named "Sasha") and Tycho, from "Penny Arcade. (A geek-based comic, which often has STRONG LANGUAGE involved, but Tycho is the one who pretty much swears in this game, anyway. Though some of the things he says are definitely NOTHING beyond PG-13; as long as you keep the strong language censored!) If you don't like strong language, you have the option to block it out; after all, you'll hear bleeps, and notice that the swear is COMPLETELY CENSORED! And that's why I like this game; it's funny, it has the option of leaving strong language censored, and it's got GREAT graphics! (Any swears said by Strong Bad are strictly be censored, however, because they don't want to make him look offensive.) I give this game 8/10, saying that this is probably one of the BEST and FUNNIEST simulators in history...and the gambling obviously isn't real; it's a poker simulator.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
Hilarious Poker SimulatorThis game is, without contest, one of the best poker games out there. I mean, come on, it's got Max! And the Heavy! Those two are bosses! Who wouldn't wanna play poker with a rabbit and a fat man?I bought this game, mainly from a friends influence, but I did like the look of it anyway. When I first played, because I had no poker experience, I was so bad at it and Max or the Heavy would keep knocking me out. I started to go on better, but then I ****ed up a game because Strong Bad knocked out Tycho, Heavy and Max so we were in a duel. I had $7,000 and he had everyone else's money plus his own. Who did you think won? He did. Finally I got good. Tycho is a very tactical player, but he folds too much. Strong Bad wins way too much money. Heavy always bets high and Max, he is my favourite in the game, always goes out really early which disappoints me. There should be more game modes of poker to play because Texas Hold'em is great and all, but people will get bored of it. The only other recommendation is to add a tutorial, because it is confusing for a new player. In case you are worried, this game does not make a real life gambling problem for you like it does to you in this game.8/10

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												It's...well... it's a poker game. It has plenty of bells and whistles thanks to the idea of featuring popular game and webcomic characters as your opponents to add plenty of flavour and chitchat to the game, but at the heart of it, it's just another poker game.Not even that, it only plays one type of poker (Texas Hold 'em) with next to no variety. The computer players do put up quite a challenge and the game is fun for a while, but in the end it's just another poker game. Which has some stability issues. It doesn't work on modern Macs and it seems to crash a lot on Windows. Plus Strongbad is really, *really* annoying. I wish you could pick and choose how many opponents and who you play against so I didn't have to listen to his voice grate in my ears.HOWEVER, I did stick with it long enough to learn how to play Texas Hold'em Poker so the game can't be that bad. Plus it's cheap. Get it if you like poker games and are intrigued by the novelty of playing against Tycho and Max.

												I have to recommend Poker Night. You'll come for poker and TF2 items, but you'll stay for the character interactions and the music. The game has a certain charm to it, and I find myself still booting it up every so often to spend some time playing. Great replay value, great characters, great game. My only hang-up is that it doesn't run well on my ASUS K-72 laptop, but the game looks great on low settings. It's $5.00 USD. If you've got a few spare bucks, there is no reason not to buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a well-implemented poker game, where you play no limit Texas Hold 'em.Your opponents are Tycho (Penny Arcade), The Heavy (Team Fortress 2), Strong Bad (Homestar Runner) and Max (Sam and Max).Poker Night's main part are the dialogues between the characters. However, you must be familiar with the characters in order to understand many of the jokes.After a while the funny dialogue will start to lose its charm as it repeats, but you can limit it or turn it off completely after you have heard all there is to hear.You can unlock new tables and poker decks for use and also you can unlock four aesthetic items for various TF2 classes.The biggest issue with the game is that there is no multiplayer option. You always play with the same opponents and everyone always starts out with $10,000.Well it is a simple game with four well known video game superstars and gives you the chance to earn TF2 items while you are playing. For that low price you can not make a mistake with a purchase.Sound 7/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 6/10Atmosphere 7/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												I honestly can't recommend this game.  It's not that it's a bad game, but the poker AI is just atrocious.  Here's a typical scenario:  I have pocket jacks pre-flop and I'm on the button.  First to act raises.  I re-raise.  Small blind goes all in.  Big blind goes all in.  First to raise goes all in.  I fold because in a real poker game, I'm guaranteed to be beat at this point.  They all turn over their cards: 10 4 off suit, 2 3 suited, and 8 5 off suit.  What the hell?!  This is not a realistic poker situation, even for beginners.  You would think playing people who are this reckless would be easy, but oh no!  Pretty much anytime I have a legit hand that I'm confident in, every single player will call my bets/ raises.  Consequently, the power of numbers works against me and the majority of the time the AI sucks out with a terrible hand.  And if you play tight, all that happens is that the other four players play reckless and they end up giving all of their chips to a single player who will now have a 4:1 stack lead over you.  That's pretty hard to overcome.  On the plus side, the animations are great and the conversation by the players is truly entertaining (minus Tycho, who comes across as extremely annoying).  If you're a fan of any of the characters/ franchises included in this game, I would recommend picking this up as that part is rather entertaining.  If you're looking for a good solid poker game however, I would avoid this as the AI is simply terrible and you will spend most of your time frustrated by it.  I would give this a 5.5/10.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												If you are buying this game with the intent of playing poker, don't bother. The AI is laughable, and not challenging in the slightest once you've learned how the bots think. The voice acting is decent, although the continuous dialog gets obnoxious quickly. On the bright side, the achievements are all relatively easy to unlock, with the exception of straight flush and four of a kind.. which are just luck based. If you're interested in this game soley for the tf2 items, it may still be worth the purchase. Just view it as paying a dollar an item or so, and if that's still worth it to you, then have at it. I'd say it's best viewed as buying an items dlc for team fotress two, rather than a game purchase - you'll be less likely to end up disappointed in that case.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2012
												First I'll ask a question: Who the hell still plays this game?The hype from TF2 unlockable items has ended, and therefore nobody plays Poker Night anymore. Poker Night at the Inventory is a largely failed attempt at having a game surviving soley on writing and humor. Failed because of their choice of crossover NPC's to play against, be it either Strongbad's narcissistic napolean complex or Tycho's sarcastic condescending passive-aggressive attitude. Nothing good can be said about gameplay, because it's nothing but Texas Hold-em, which you can play in real life for free. But if you REALLY want to get TF2 items from cards, then get friends together and play online or real-life poker where each of you wagers one of your hats, that would make for a more enjoyable time than listening to four wise♥♥♥♥♥NPC's talk smack about you.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I would avoid this game.It's not bad, necessarily, but it's not very good either.  Alright, so it's poker and that's fine.  The enemy AI does not play very well at all  and it's usually very easy to dupe them into losing either by bluffing hard or slowly raising.  It's predictable AI, and as far as I could tell, every character uses the same or similar AI, so don't expect to have a great time if you're a poker fan.The idea is to knock out characters by taking all of their money so that you're the last man standing.  At the time this game was partially about some of the TF2 items you could acquire, but that's not why I picked it up.I picked it up because Penny Arcade's Tycho voice Tycho for it, and he had been saying it was a lot of fun to record.  It also starred Strongbad and Heavy (Tf2) so I figured, what the hell.  Five bucks.  I easily got five dollars of entertainment out of Night at the Inventory, but that's not exactly saying much: maybe 3-5 hours of playing?  The dialogue is humorous once, maybe twice, but there isn't so much of it, so the characters repeat themselves frequently and surprisingly early in the gameplay.  While you can limit how often the characters speak, you can't eliminate it.  By default the game interrupts and slows down gameplay in favor of the dialogue, which sort of makes sense as the characters were such a huge (the only?) selling point.Of special note are the achievements, most of which are luck based (win with a certain type of hand).  For a little while I had been trying to 100% it but I just gave up after getting bored.  Trying to land specific hands in an AI poker game just isn't fun.So, if you're looking for maybe an hour of amusement, yeah, get it.  The dialogue is great once or twice, like I said, and I did very much enjoy the characters.  There just isn't enough dialogue to go much longer than that, and the gameplay just can't hold this one up so everything just falls flat.  Maybe if you're interested in the characters and it's up someday for 99 cents go for it, otherwise give it a pass.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2010
												You may be saying to yourself, "WELL GEE KILLZ OBVIOUSLY YOU ARE RECOMMENDING THIS FOR THE TF2 ITEMS," put your rant on hold. Yes the final straw for this game was the TF2 items because I didn't know the rules of poker and how to play. I myself personally love both the Heavy and Max (the bunny from Sam & Max) so I had this game on thought for a while. I honestly can say that even after getting the TF2 unlocks, I can't stop playing this game. The dialogue is not only pure gold, but the music of the Inventory is outstanding and really sets the atmosphere for this game. Telltale didn't just mess around by putting 4 characters together you can play poker with, they actually put strong and believable dialogue that actually makes you feel like you are playing poker with this strange set of people instead of just characters in a video game. It's clever, it's hysterical, and it's $5. Texas Hold 'Em is really easy to learn and you'll have a great time learning the game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun and simple Texas Hold'em simulator featuring familiar faces from various games offered on Steam.  If you like playing computer opponents in poker, this is fun and humorous.  There is no multiplayer function.  The game loses it's humor fast, and there isn't any DLC, so replay value is pretty low.  Unlike the sequel to this game, there are no DLC to win by playing this game.  Overall, it is just alright, but not spectacular.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												First off: Why are you wanting this game? Either one: You want to play poker with some video game characters (Really?) or two: you want promo items in Team Fortress 2.I got this crap for #2.Cons -The game seems.... VERY unrealistic at times, as in, 6 Aces played in a single game kind of unrealistic (This has happened).Boring. After about 30 minutes, you understand what to do. Either play like these are REAL people and bet like a real person, or you trick the bots into 'thinking' you got good cards (There ARE guides out there to 'farm' the items off the characters: go all in EVERY TIME).Poker Night is painful. The bots know exactly what your cards are, but they just play along. Their cards sometimes (4/5) have most of your cards. $5 - $10 for petty gameplay and items.The some of the items are not very good either, For instance, the Liscence to Maim looks like an upgraded Merc. Badge.Pros +TF2 Items.Fun dialogue. The characters DO have some fun chit-chat with each other.

												This poker game has no playback value, yet is good for a couple of hours whilst you listen to the character's chat. During this game, the characters may pull out an item which, if you knock them out of the game, can be used in Team Fortress 2. content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												So this is possibly the most disappointing game I've ever played.  Not the worst game by any means, but very disappointing.The poker itself is slow as molasses.  After you've seen all the animations and dialogue 20 times, you really want to be able to skip through and play poker.  I mean, yanno, it's a poker game - ostensibly.Two hours and the game, which should be infinitely replayable, is boring and stale.  Terrible abuse of the IPs in this game.  Absolutely a shame.  I'm confused how this got a sequel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2010
												This is a great implentation of the popular Texas Hold 'em style of Poker. It's simpler then dealing with a whole hand on your own, and a good introduction to Poker rules and gameplay. That aside, what makes this a fun game is the implementation of several famous and well-known characters, namely Max from the Sam and Max series, The Heavy from Team fortress Two, Tycho from the Penny Arcade Comic (Yes we find out what his voice is like!), and Strongbad from Homestar Runner. What makes this game particularly fun is the banter and conversation that occurs about the poker table during play and while you consider your cards. Each character's personality shines through boldly and mixes with the others in unique, interesting, and unpredictable ways that makes it all the more exciting. Sometimes I forget I'm playing poker as I listen to the banter, comments, and hijinks that go on. If you like any of the characters that will be at the table, or want some cool swag to wear in TF2, buy it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												An overall decent Texas Hold'em simulator, but the real stars here are your opponents, seeming almost randomly selected based on their backgrounds: Max from the Sam & Max franchise, Strongbad of Homestar Runner, The Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Tycho of Penny Arcade. Telltale Games has outdone themselves creating an immersive experience with these third party characters, matching their personality to a T when it comes to dialogue and interactions: Max tells stories about fighting crime with Sam, Strongbad rants and raves just like with his email videos, Heavy thinks of the chips as his 'team' and blames the Spy whenever he gets a bad hand, and Tycho makes various different tabletop, card, and video game references. They play the game exactly like you would expect them to, which is a great feat in itself considering the licensing TTG must have had to go through. Even though Poker Night 2 is on the horizon and to be released this month, the original should not be overlooked. There are still special crossover TF2 items to be unlocked, and you won't be seeing any of the original cast (aside from cameos by Max) in the sequel. Definitely worth the buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2013
												This game is a pleasent little time waster. Something to occupy an uneventful evening where you don't want to play anything strenuous but don't want to feel numb in what you do play. Its relaxing but still can be a mental challenge, with a bit of witty humour thrown in for good measure.Now I only wish this wasn't the last hooraw for Strong Bad and most importantly Homestarrunner.com. With the exception of a Christmas special in '10 this was the last I seen or heard from the Brothers Chaps. Its truely a shame, I thought that if anything their cartoons and humour were getting BETTER!! I felt Homestar was finally starting to crawl out of Strong Bad's shadow and become something more than a dimless retard, but an excitable spaz that isn't entirely aware of where he is or what he says but still a very plucky gogetter......*SIGH*Go play this game

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I tried Poker Night 1 and 2, and 1 is the more-fun game.  The personalities in 2 are a little annoying, and the gameplay isn't balanced among the players (Ash won the first 8 pots I played, usually bluffing, but he had the nuts every time he was called down).  It's a fun game for a pretty cheap price, and all of the characters have their quirks that are a lot of fun.  There is one pretty huge bug: you can't seem to min-raise pre-flop.  If everyone calls a 600 big blind and it comes to you, your min-raise button says "$1,200 total", but using it raises $1,200 to $1,800 total.  I'm not sure if this happens 100% of the time or just in certain conditions, but it was certainly repeatable for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2011
												Oh the countless times I've played this, the dialogue is witty the first few times you hear it (Except for Tycho's animal problems) but then it gets old quick. You get to play with a group of 3 online gaming celebrities and 1 gamer that owns a comic with his friend whose original character design you play against in No holds barred Texas Holdem. The only real purposes this game has is to get you exclusive reskins of items for Team Fortress 2 or to hone your poker skills and do whatever the hell you feel like. The story (why does there need to be one) is that you are a back alley poker player who finds a neat little underground hang-out called The Inventory, a man you can recognize as Mr.Winslow from Tales of Monkey Island guides you to your table and referees the game. Along the way in the opening cutscene you may recognize some characters from Strongbad and Max's games. Unfortunately no appearances from the Red Team have been noted (not counting the cards of TF2). 6/10 at best.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Poker Night at the Inventory is a comedic poker game that you enjoy together with some famous video game and comic book characters. Among them is Heavy from Team Fortress 2 and Max from Sam & Max. The game is somewhat what you would expect - A poker game. You compete in tournaments were you get the chance to win Team Fortress 2 unlockables, achievements and more. However, personally I think it lacks some depth. Sure there are funny conversations going on but they soon get repetitive and dull. Also the lack of multiplayer or even global leaderboards kind of depletes the purpose of gambling.I recommend the game because of the low price. Go get it if you enjoy poker!
